LH.10.01.question: Typically, the third step in the user interface design process is what?

LH.10.02.question: Generally, headings on a paper form should be with Arial size 24 bold; the main text should be Times New Roman size 12. Subheadings should be Tahoma size 14, bold and italic and underlined. This makes a form easier to read and to delineate sections.

LH.10.03.question: At least one study suggests that some variation be appropriate in user interface design as the study suggests that when all forms tend to look the same, it can be confusing to some users.

LH.10.04.question: Omar has designed a paper form using 'sans serif' fonts and for his screen (or web) forms he has used 'serif' fonts. He is exercising good user interface design practices.

LH.10.05.question: Typically, the first step in the user interface design process is what?

LH.10.06.question: Which of the following is NOT a common Interface Evaluation technique?

LH.10.07.question: Interface evaluations almost always do what?

LH.10.08.question: Compare data against a data base (or file) to ensure that they are correct.

LH.10.10.question: Which of the following is NOT a suggestion for preventing mistakes?

LH.10.11.question: This defines the basic components of the interface and how they work together to provide functionality to users.

LH.10.12.question: Displays selected item in one-line box that opens to reveal list of choices.

LH.10.13.question: In Use Scenario Development, the goal is:

LH.10.14.question: This output is poor at helping users recognize precise numeric values and should be replaced by tables when precision is important.

LH.10.15.question: When implementing the 'minimize user effort' factor, most interface designers follow what rule?

LH.10.16.question: Approximately what percent of men are color blind (and thus improper use of color can impair their ability to read information)

LH.10.17.question: This is used when an extra digit is added to a coded field to make sure it the entered data is correct (like Social Security numbers).

LH.10.18.question: Forms should have version numbers so that users, analysts and programmers can identify outdated materials.

LH.10.19.question: This is an outline of the steps that the users perform to accomplish some part of their work.

LH.10.20.question: Informs the user that the computer system is working properly to perform a task that may take several seconds.

LH.10.21.question: Informs the user that he or she has attempted to do something to which the system cannot respond.

LH.10.22.question: Bob is designing input screens for a re-designed system for the shipping and inventory department. For order forms, he puts Zip code first (as the database will take the zip code and look up the city and state); for receiving forms, he puts them in the order of city, then state, then zip code. His design choices will help experienced users be more productive.

LH.10.23.question: Bias can be introduced into a report by the way in which lists of data are sorted.

LH.10.24.question: Asks the user to verify that he or she really wants to perform the action selected.

LH.10.25.question: The objective of an interface evaluation is what?

LH.10.26.question: Used as a shortcut for experienced Users.

LH.10.27.question: User experience refers to minimizing the number of clicks or commands to go from one field to another.

LH.10.28.question: Which is NOT true about the content awareness design principle?

LH.10.29.question: The following is used as a second-level menu, often from a menu bar.

LH.10.30.question: When designing navigational controls, which is NOT commonly assumed?

LH.10.31.question: Space is generally at a premium on forms and reports, thus squeezing information onto forms is considered a wise business decision.

LH.10.32.question: Presents a list of choices in a box.

LH.10.33.question: Jamal is creating a user interface. He wants what he calls an 'oops' button on every screen and form (or an 'undo' button). This is a good design consideration.

LH.10.34.question: Used when user does something that is not permitted or not possible.

LH.10.35.question: Used when user selects a potentially dangerous choice, such as deleting a file.

LH.10.36.question: The following is used as a main menu for a Web-based system.

LH.10.37.question: Ensure that combinations of data are valid.

LH.10.38.question: Used seldom or never - only if there is insufficient room for check boxes or radio buttons

LH.10.39.question: The first principle of designing navigation controls is what?

LH.10.40.question: Used when only one item can be selected from a set of mutually exclusive items.

LH.10.41.question: The following is used as a shortcut to commands for experienced users.

LH.10.42.question: Ensures that data are of the right type (e.g., numeric) and in the right format (e.g., month, day, year).

LH.10.43.question: The following is used when the user needs to change several settings or perform several related commands.

LH.10.44.question: When creating navigational controls, you should either not display a command that cannot be used or 'gray' it out (where it shows, but cannot be used).

LH.10.45.question: Informs the user that the system has accomplished what it was asked to do.

LH.10.46.question: If a particular form or screen is used by a cadre of experienced users very frequently (like an accounting entry system), 'ease of use' should be a high priority on these system interfaces.

LH.10.47.question: When creating user interfaces, analysts should examine DFDs and use cases to see how users commonly perform various processes.

LH.10.48.question: Which is generally NOT true for interface evaluations?

LH.10.49.question: This is used when you want to verify that data fits within correct minimum and maximum values.

LH.10.50.question: Which of the following might be a good choice of an icon for saving on a user interface?

LH.10.51.question: Infrequent users prefer user interfaces with 'ease of learning' features (like more explicit menu choices, clear directions).

LH.10.52.question: Michelle is designing a series of user interfaces for a CRM system. She goes back and forth between various steps of use cases, DFDs, ERDs and JAD session notes.

LH.10.53.question: A special type of drop-down list box that permits user to type as well as scroll the list.

LH.10.54.question: Used when an activity takes more than seven seconds.

LH.10.55.question: Presents a complete list of mutually exclusive choices, each with a circle in front.

LH.10.56.question: Ensures that all required data have been entered.

LH.10.57.question: Interface Structures cannot directly interface with other interface structures on other menus and submenus, only the interface structures on the same menu or submenu.

LH.10.58.question: Experienced users prefer user interfaces with 'ease of learning' features.

LH.10.60.question: Some systems that are used infrequently should probably emphasize:

LH.10.61.question: Used when there is insufficient room to display all choices.

LH.10.62.question: Typically, the second step in the user interface design process is what?

LH.10.63.question: Ensures that numeric data are within correct minimum and maximum values.

LH.10.64.question: Used when entering a numeric value.

LH.10.65.question: Typically, the fourth step in the user interface design process is what?

LH.10.66.question: This report is used when a user needs brief information on many items.

LH.10.67.question: Presents a complete list of choices, each with a square box in front.

LH.10.68.question: This is used when all combinations of data are valid (like birth year is prior to marriage year).

LH.10.69.question: Research shows that in an ideal world a menu should contain no more than four items and submenus should contain no fewer than six items.

LH.10.70.question: It is better to make menus how?

LH.10.72.question: There are many types of reports, they include which of the following?

LH.10.73.question: If the density on a single page form is too high, it might not be as effective for some users as creating a two-page form.

LH.10.74.question: One strong suggestion for navigation design is what?

LH.10.75.question: Range checks will validate if the data is numeric with two decimal places.

LH.10.76.question: The following is used as a main menu for a system.

LH.10.77.question: Provides additional information about the system and its components.

LH.10.78.question: This is used when several fields must be entered before the form can be processed.

LH.10.79.question: Colors and patterns add pizzazz to a screen form and aid in its readability.

LH.10.80.question: Aesthetics refers to designing information that can be navigated in three-clicks or less.

LH.10.81.question: For screen forms and reports, you should use a font of at least size 12.

LH.10.82.question: A use scenario is one commonly used what?

LH.10.83.question: User interface design is a three-step process: (1) analyze the DFDs and use cases; (2) develop the interface diagrams; and (3) create the interface design prototype.

LH.10.84.question: Which of these are good strategies to succeed in this course?

LH.10.85.question: Scroll arrows moves directionally through numeric range.

LH.10.86.question: Used when several items can be selected from a list of items.

LH.10.87.question: Typically, the fifth step in the user interface design process is what?

LH.10.88.question: Novice or infrequent users of an interface (both paper and screen) prefer interfaces with low density like under 25%.

LH.10.89.question: Mike is the analyst creating a report. It is easy for him to unintentionally create a biased report.

LH.10.90.question: This is used when fields are numeric or contain coded data.

LH.10.91.question: Interface Structure Design defines the application coding structure used (such as developing prototypes in Visual Basic).

LH.10.92.question: The first principle of designing navigational controls is to prevent users from making mistakes.
